Jack G. Shaheen Papers: Arabs in U.S. Film and Television
Shaheen, Jack G, 1935-
Shaheen, Jack G, 1935-

28.5 Linear Feet in 36 boxes
1940-2002 bulk Materials are in English, with a few items in Arabic. Born in 1935 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Dr. Jack G. Shaheen, professor, author film and legal consultant, has studied and documented the history of damaging stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims in American media. Shaheen is currently (2011) a Distinguished Visiting Scholar at New York University’s Asian/Pacific/American Institute and The Hagop Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies. This collection contains correspondence, research notes, published and unpublished writings, transcripts of his testimony in legal cases pertaining to discrimination against Arab Americans; research files (the bulk of the collection) that contain printed ephemera (sometimes annotated), including advertisements, clippings, reviews, editorial cartoons, as well as some motion picture posters and still photographs; two boxes of comic books containing Arab characters; two boxes of audiocassettes, consisting of interviews of Shaheen, some from the mass media, and recordings of radio programs.
Access Restrictions
This collection is currently closed pending processing.
Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Jack G. Shaheen Videos (Videos 015) contains nearly 3,000 motion pictures spanning from late-19th century silent films to contemporary Hollywood productions, and television programs including comedies, dramas, cartoons, as well as commercials, on VHS and DVDs, that depict Arabs and Arab Americans. For additional information about this collection, contact the repository at tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.
Scope and Contents
This collection contains correspondence, research notes, published and unpublished writings, transcripts of his testimony in legal cases pertaining to discrimination against Arab Americans; research files (the bulk of the collection) that contain printed ephemera (sometimes annotated), including advertisements, clippings, reviews, editorial cartoons, film scripts, including those for which he served as a consultant, as well as some motion picture posters and still photographs; two boxes of comic books containing Arab characters; two boxes of audiocassettes, consisting of interviews of Shaheen, some from the mass media, and recordings of radio programs.
Historical/Biographical Note
Dr. Jack G. Shaheen (1935- ), professor, author, film (Syriana, Three Kings)and legal consultant, has studied and documented the history of damaging stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims in American media. He also has connected their development to the portrayals of other marginalized groups including Jews, Native Americans, Asian Americans, Latinos, and African Americans. Shaheen is currently (2011) a Distinguished Visiting Scholar at New York University’s Asian/Pacific/American Institute and The Hagop Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies. Shaheen is the author of The TV Arab (1984), Reel Bad Arabs: How Hollywood Vilifies a People (2001), and Guilty: Hollywood's Verdict on Arabs after 9/11 (2008).
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor. The collection is grouped in to two series reflecting two separate accretions of the collection received from the donor in 2010 and 2012.
Use Restrictions
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Jack G. Shaheen, the creator of this collecion, were transferred to New York University in 2010. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.
